    Highlights

    •
    Redesign of multigene pathways for expression in prokaryotes and eukaryotes
    •
    Development and mobilization of hybrid cross-kingdom expression technology
    •
    Discovery of tyrocitabines, a class of nucleotide metabolites from the human microbiome
    •
    Tyrocitabine biosynthesis invokes unusual tRNA synthetase-mediated orthoester formation

    Summary

    Small molecules encoded by biosynthetic pathways mediate cross-species interactions and harbor untapped potential, which has provided valuable compounds for medicine and biotechnology. Since studying biosynthetic gene clusters in their native context is often difficult, alternative efforts rely on heterologous expression, which is limited by host-specific metabolic capacity and regulation. Here, we describe a computational-experimental technology to redesign genes and their regulatory regions with hybrid elements for cross-species expression in Gram-negative and -positive bacteria and eukaryotes, decoupling biosynthetic capacity from host-range constraints to activate silenced pathways. These synthetic genetic elements enabled the discovery of a class of microbiome-derived nucleotide metabolites—tyrocitabines—from Lactobacillus iners. Tyrocitabines feature a remarkable orthoester-phosphate, inhibit translational activity, and invoke unexpected biosynthetic machinery, including a class of “Amadori synthases” and “abortive” tRNA synthetases. Our approach establishes a general strategy for the redesign, expression, mobilization, and characterization of genetic elements in diverse organisms and communities.

    Graphical abstract

    Keywords

    1. synthetic biology
    2. secondary metabolism
    3. natural products
    4. pathway engineering
    5. microbial genetics
    6. genome engineering
    7. computer-aided design

    ) have been used to self-mobilize and chromosomally integrate heterologous cargo in a variety of strains. These and other integrative strategies—e.g., phage-assisted integration, site-specific integrases (Du et al., 2015
    38.
    Du, D. ∙ Wang, L. ∙ Tian, Y. ...
    Genome engineering and direct cloning of antibiotic gene clusters via phage φBT1 integrase-mediated site-specific recombination in Streptomyces
    Sci. Rep. 2015; 5:8740
    Crossref
    Scopus (54)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and Cas-transposases (Rubin et al., 2022
    100.
    Rubin, B.E. ∙ Diamond, S. ∙ Cress, B.F. ...
    Species- and site-specific genome editing in complex bacterial communities
    Nat. Microbiol. 2022; 7:34-47
    Crossref
    Scopus (28)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    )—have limitations in host range, which remain a focus of active research.
    In this study, we present a computational and experimental strategy to redesign multigene biological pathways for mobilization, expression, and characterization in versatile organisms. In our approach (Figure 1), the orphan BGCs are computationally redesigned into synthetic genetic elements (SGEs) and functionalized for expression across diverse hosts. This is enabled by the development of hybrid transcriptional expression signals for both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. These SGEs are mobilized into both kingdoms, where pathway-targeted metabolomics is used to identify key molecular features and characterize the structures and functions of output metabolites. We demonstrate that this approach can productively animate orphan BGCs, which enabled the discovery of an unexpected route for the biosynthesis of a class of bioactive nucleotide metabolites encoded in the human microbiome. These metabolites expand our knowledge of the biochemistry catalyzed by otherwise canonical genes, such as tRNA synthetases. Ultimately, we anticipate that our technology will establish a broader framework for functionalizing genetic elements across diverse species, including nonmodel organisms and communities.

    Results

    Computer-aided design of SGEs

    Expression of BGCs involves sequential layers of control exerted at the level of transcription, translation, and enzymatic activity, which is often mediated through post-translational modification and the availability of input metabolites (Temme et al., 2012
    117.
    Temme, K. ∙ Zhao, D. ∙ Voigt, C.A.
    Refactoring the nitrogen fixation gene cluster from Klebsiella oxytoca
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2012; 109:7085-7090
    Crossref
    Scopus (268)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Through evolutionary divergence, the regulation of these layers is expectedly strain- and environment-specific. To decouple biosynthetic capacity from strain-specific regulatory layers, we developed a computer-aided design (CAD: cad-sge.com) strategy to redesign BGCs at the level of an individual coding sequence (CDS), transcription, and translation, establishing synthetic design principles to enable versatile cross-kingdom host-range expression (Figure 2A).
    We assess and implement redesign principles at the individual CDS level (Figure 2B). Commonly used codon optimization approaches (e.g., codon adaptation index [CAI] and tRNA adaptation index [TAI]; Mauro and Chappell, 2014
    79.
    Mauro, V.P. ∙ Chappell, S.A.
    A critical analysis of codon optimization in human therapeutics
    Trends Mol. Med. 2014; 20:604-613
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) are constrained because they are tailored for a target species, whereas our approach simultaneously designs constructs for diverse prokaryotic and eukaryotic taxa, each with greatly varying GC content, tRNA abundances, and codon usage. Additionally, the general utility of codon optimization for heterologous expression remains an unresolved subject, where large-scale screens fail to capture a general correlation between codon adaptation and expression levels (Kudla et al., 2009
    60.
    Kudla, G. ∙ Murray, A.W. ∙ Tollervey, D. ...
    Coding-sequence determinants of gene expression in Escherichia coli
    Science. 2009; 324:255-258
    Crossref
    Scopus (1002)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    To address these constraints and enable the versatile expression of SGEs, we developed an alternative CDS-level optimization protocol to capture more host-independent optimization parameters, accounting for six factors (Figure 2B). First, individual CDSs are converted from amino acid to nucleotide sequence; here, the baseline codon usage distribution is based on the codon usage of highly expressed genes of a species of choice. For the experiments in this work, we utilized Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis base selections. The base codon distribution is depleted of canonically inhibiting codons (Figure S1A).
    Second, codon usage at the N terminus has been shown to significantly impact gene expression, largely due to the 5′ RNA secondary structure (Angov, 2011
    4.
    Angov, E.
    Codon usage: nature’s roadmap to expression and folding of proteins
    Biotechnol. J. 2011; 6:650-659
    Crossref
    Scopus (152)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). This feature is conserved in prokaryotes and eukaryotes and serves as a useful parameter to promote the host-range versatility. We analyzed the predicted 5′ mRNA structure of E. coli genes before and after codon optimization in silico. Using Vienna RNA Suite (Lorenz et al., 2011
    75.
    Lorenz, R. ∙ Bernhart, S.H. ∙ Höner zu Siederdissen, C. ...
    ViennaRNA package 2.0
    Algorithms Mol. Biol. 2011; 6:26
    Crossref
    Scopus (2441)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we calculated the minimum folding energy across each CDS using a 30-bp sliding window. This data highlight the depletion of secondary structure in native gene sequences, particularly in the 36-bp region at the 5′-terminus, consistent with prior findings (Figure 2C; Goodman et al., 2013
    45.
    Goodman, D.B. ∙ Church, G.M. ∙ Kosuri, S.
    Causes and effects of N-terminal codon bias in bacterial genes
    Science. 2013; 342:475-479
    Crossref
    Scopus (366)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). This depletion of structure is reproducible across phyla (Figure S1B). If CDSs are recoded by the standard CAI approach (Mauro and Chappell, 2014
    79.
    Mauro, V.P. ∙ Chappell, S.A.
    A critical analysis of codon optimization in human therapeutics
    Trends Mol. Med. 2014; 20:604-613
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), using the codon distribution of highly expressed E. coli genes, this 5′-thermodynamic property dissipates (Figure 2C). Instead, our algorithm selects for synonymous sequences that result in low 5′ secondary structure.
    We next investigated the impact of genetic design parameters on 108 recoded GFP variants. We found that the most significant impact on GFP expression came from codon usage at the 12 N-terminal amino acids (Figures S1C–S1E). Previous studies had noted an enrichment of less adapted codons among the first 30–50 codons (Tuller et al., 2010
    123.
    Tuller, T. ∙ Carmi, A. ∙ Vestsigian, K. ...
    An evolutionarily conserved mechanism for controlling the efficiency of protein translation
    Cell. 2010; 141:344-354
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (571)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Through subsequent FACS-seq experiments, it was found that secondary structure was the predominant determinant, while codon usage was a tolerable covariate (Goodman et al., 2013
    45.
    Goodman, D.B. ∙ Church, G.M. ∙ Kosuri, S.
    Causes and effects of N-terminal codon bias in bacterial genes
    Science. 2013; 342:475-479
    Crossref
    Scopus (366)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Interestingly, we found that even when selecting for low (<3.5 kcal/mol) 5′-mRNA secondary structure, the codon usage remained impactful (Figure S1C), a finding distinct from the previous studies and worthy of further investigation. At the N terminus, using codons enriched in E. coli highly expressed genes resulted in higher fluorescence than that when using the codons enriched in the FACS-seq assay. Additionally, for the remainder of the open reading frame, we found no significant correlation between CAI and protein expression. This suggests that the aggregate codon adaptation was not strongly predictive of the expression strength. Indeed, GFP genes recoded to match E. coli’s codon usage performed comparably in E. coli to those recoded to match B. subtilis codon usage, which were neutrally randomized or were enriched in inhibitory codons to create poor CAI values. This lack of correlation suggests that codon usage is not strictly a barrier for broad host-range expression.
    Third, we designed synthetic 5′ UTR sequences incorporating hybrid eukaryotic and prokaryotic elements that are known to impact gene expression in various microbial taxa (Figure 2D). Our implementation builds off the ribosome binding site (RBS) calculator, a previously described thermodynamic translation initiation model (Salis et al., 2009
    102.
    Salis, H.M. ∙ Mirsky, E.A. ∙ Voigt, C.A.

    Nat. Biotechnol. 2009; 27:946-950

    ), which was expanded to include a stricter Shine-Dalgarno sequence requirement and start codon spacing preference (Vellanoweth and Rabinowitz, 1992
    126.
    Vellanoweth, R.L. ∙ Rabinowitz, J.C.

    Mol. Microbiol. 1992; 6:1105-1114

The variable “N” positions are then iteratively mutated until the desired predicted translation initiation rates (TIRs) are reached, tailored specifically for each CDS. In this study, thermodynamic parameters to calculate TIR were based on empirical data collected in E. coli (Salis et al., 2009
    102.
    Salis, H.M. ∙ Mirsky, E.A. ∙ Voigt, C.A.
    Automated design of synthetic ribosome binding sites to control protein expression
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2009; 27:946-950

    Next, E. coli genes were recoded 100 times each to quantify undesired transcription termination and translation initiation signals resulting from codon optimization. We found widespread emergence of the internal prokaryotic translation start sites, which were predicted using the RBS calculator parameters (Salis et al., 2009
    102.
    Salis, H.M. ∙ Mirsky, E.A. ∙ Voigt, C.A.
    Automated design of synthetic ribosome binding sites to control protein expression
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2009; 27:946-950
    Crossref
    Scopus (1220)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). An average of 3.8 internal RBSs appeared per gene-recoding attempt (Figure 2E). In native genes, aberrant internal translation initiation is largely disfavored, even in the presence of Shine-Dalgarno motifs upstream of ATG codons, as demonstrated by ribosomal profiling experiments (Li et al., 2012
    69.
    Li, G.-W. ∙ Oh, E. ∙ Weissman, J.S.

    Nature. 2012; 484:538-541
    Crossref
    Scopus (446)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). However, the mechanism and sequence features by which internal initiation is avoided are not understood (Saito et al., 2020
    101.
    Saito, K. ∙ Green, R. ∙ Buskirk, A.R.
    Translational initiation in E. coli occurs at the correct sites genome-wide in the absence of mRNA-rRNA base-pairing
    Elife. 2020; 9:e55002
    Crossref
    Scopus (32)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Additionally, we found that rho-independent terminators spontaneously appear in 19% of the recoding attempts, as identified using the predictive tool transtermHP (Kingsford et al., 2007
    59.
    Kingsford, C.L. ∙ Ayanbule, K. ∙ Salzberg, S.L.
    Rapid, accurate, computational discovery of Rho-independent transcription terminators illuminates their relationship to DNA uptake
    Genome Biol. 2007; 8:R22
    Crossref
    Scopus (370)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Figure 2E). Accordingly, as the fifth design principle, we algorithmically depleted NTG codons in all three forward coding frames. When an NTG codon cannot be avoided, the upstream sequence is then synonymously modified to structurally inhibit internal ribosome entry. These efforts significantly decreased the number of predicted internal translation initiation sites from 3.8 to 0.6 per gene (p < 0.001 using a two-tailed paired Z-test) (Figure 2E). As the sixth design principle, our algorithm scans and removes the deleterious terminators, bringing the computed value to 0%.

    Eukaryotic transcription with synthetic promoters optimized for cross-kingdom expression

    We next designed a prokaryotic-eukaryotic regulatory element for cross-kingdom transcription initiation. In prokaryotes, multiple genes can be concurrently transcribed in an operon. However, each CDS generally utilizes a distinct promoter and terminator in eukaryotes. Given this requirement, the 5′ sequence of each CDS is further extended to include regulatory elements to initiate transcription in yeast. Our design creates intergenic regions depleted in nucleosome occupancy, which is strongly correlated with both efficient transcription initiation and poly-A termination in eukaryotes (Ichikawa et al., 2016
    48.

    To develop 5′ sequences designed to initiate eukaryotic transcription, we constructed an expanded library of synthetic yeast promoters that addressed four key requirements of cross-kingdom SGE design (Figures 3A and 3B). First, these eukaryotic elements should not interfere with bacterial expression. Second, sequence length was minimized to reduce synthesis costs and minimize the negative impact of untranslated sequences on bacterial mRNA stability (Cetnar and Salis, 2021
    20.
    Cetnar, D.P. ∙ Salis, H.M.
    Systematic quantification of sequence and structural determinants controlling mRNA stability in bacterial operons
    ACS Synth. Biol. 2021; 10:318-332
    Crossref
    Scopus (5)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Third, we minimized the sequence homology to prevent deletions through homologous recombination. Fourth, promoters were screened for predicted terminators and RBSs. We adopted a previously reported framework to achieve robust eukaryotic expression by arraying synthetic 10-bp upstream activity sequences (UASs) (6 distinct sequences), 30-bp core sequences (9 distinct sequences), a consensus TATA box (TATAAAG), and random 30-bp spacers (Figure 3C; Data S1) (Redden and Alper, 2015
    96.
    Redden, H. ∙ Alper, H.S.
    The development and characterization of synthetic minimal yeast promoters
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:7810
    Crossref
    Scopus (151)
    PubMed

    139.
    Zhang, Z. ∙ Dietrich, F.S.
    Mapping of transcription start sites in Saccharomyces cerevisiae using 5′ SAGE
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2005; 33:2838-2851

    We tested the impact of UAS number and the depletion of nucleosome occupancy at the TATA box and TSS, which is characteristic of strong promoters (Ichikawa et al., 2016
    48.
    Ichikawa, Y. ∙ Morohashi, N. ∙ Tomita, N. ...

    Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2016; 476:57-62
    Crossref

    ; Figure S2A). For the latter, the primary sequence of the spacers was interspaced with poly-A or poly-T 5-mers, guided by the NuPop hidden Markov model for predicting nucleosome position (Xi et al., 2010
    136.
    Xi, L. ∙ Fondufe-Mittendorf, Y. ∙ Xia, L. ...
    Predicting nucleosome positioning using a duration hidden Markov model
    BMC Bioinformatics. 2010; 11:346
    Crossref
    Scopus (95)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Figure S2B). Using a yeast-optimized GFP (mUkGFP) (Kaishima et al., 2016
    55.
    Kaishima, M. ∙ Ishii, J. ∙ Matsuno, T. ...
    Expression of varied GFPs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae: codon optimization yields stronger than expected expression and fluorescence intensity
    Sci. Rep. 2016; 6:35932
    Crossref
    Scopus (37)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we measured the impact of these variables on gene expression. Increasing the number (3–5) of UASs increased the expression levels 2.4-fold (3 UASs, p < 0.001) and 21-fold (5 UASs, p < 0.0001). With 5 UASs, the expression was comparable to the strong tef1 promoter of S. cerevisiae. Additionally, the depletion of nucleosome occupancy increased the expression levels 8.2-fold (p < 0.01) (Figure 3D).
    We expanded the library to construct and characterize 48 synthetic hybrid promoters (Data S1). To functionally test this library, promoter-GFP cassettes were cloned on an E. coli/S. cerevisiae shuttle vector, pYP (Figures 3B and S6A). Synthetic promoters spanned a 22-fold range of activity levels, with many meeting or exceeding the strength of the native tef1 and adh1 promoters (Figure 3E). As predicted, nucleosome depletion broadly generated promoters with higher activity (p < 0.001). At the library level, promoters with 5 UASs did not necessarily exhibit higher expression than those with 3 or 4 UASs (Figure S3E). Instead, we found that, for any given promoter, UASs can be reliably used to tune expression upward. To demonstrate the impact of UAS quantity on expression levels, we increased the number of UASs from 3 to 5 in three weak promoters (YP2, YP7, and YP8). In two of the three promoters tested, this resulted in a significant dose-dependent increase in expression (p < 0.0001) (Figure S3F), providing a basis for rational pathway engineering through promoter tuning. GFP fluorescence in S. cerevisiae strongly correlated with RNA levels (r2 = 0.92), confirming that differences in promoter strength were determined at the transcriptional level (Figure 3G).
    When these constructs were shuttled into E. coli BL21(DE3), we hypothesized that the fluorescence level would be steady since the bacterial transcription/translation signals were held constant. A small subset of promoters exhibited attenuated expression (Figure 3F). The degree of attenuation in E. coli was not meaningfully correlated with the expression strength in S. cerevisiae (Figure 3I). Using qRT-PCR, we found that only some of the variability could be explained at the mRNA level, as RNA levels differed by less than 3-fold, suggesting the presence of contributing effects at the translational level (Figure S3C). We next swapped the mUkGFP reporter with an eGFP reporter to study the impact of distinct gene sequences. These two genes share no significant nucleotide sequence similarity, as evaluated with BLAST alignment. Promoters were correlated in strength across the two reporters (r2 = 0.42) (Figures 3H and S3D), indicating that expression level trends were largely independent of the downstream gene sequence. Taken together, this library of synthetic promoters can be appended to the 5′ sequence of our redesigned CDSs to activate BGCs in both E. coli and S. cerevisiae.

    Expanding bacterial expression with an inducible T7 RNA polymerase expression circuit

    To drive bacterial transcription, we selected the bacteriophage T7 RNA polymerase (T7RNAP) and cognate T7 promoter (pT7) system, given its orthogonality, processivity, and host-independence (Tabor, 2001
    116.
    Tabor, S.
    Expression using the T7 RNA polymerase/promoter system
    Curr. Protoc. Mol. Biol. 2001; 11:16.2.1-16.2.11
    Google Scholar
    ). Because transcription from pT7 is constrained by the cognate T7RNAP, the major challenge was in expressing the T7RNAP in a host versatile manner. Our approach also sought to achieve titratable expression since T7RNAP-overexpressed genes can accumulate up to 30% of the total cellular protein and sequester 50% of the translation capacity (Segall-Shapiro et al., 2014
    106.
    Segall-Shapiro, T.H. ∙ Meyer, A.J. ∙ Ellington, A.D. ...
    A ‘resource allocator’ for transcription based on a highly fragmented T7 RNA polymerase

    Crossref
    Scopus (123)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), resulting in fitness defects and suboptimal biosynthetic pathway functionality (Scott et al., 2010
    105.
    Scott, M. ∙ Gunderson, C.W. ∙ Mateescu, E.M. ...
    Interdependence of cell growth and gene expression: origins and consequences
    Science. 2010; 330:1099-1102
    Crossref
    Scopus (769)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To provide a balance between robustness and titratability, we expanded upon the UBER system, which couples positive and negative feedback loops to modulate gene expression (Kushwaha and Salis, 2015
    62.
    Kushwaha, M. ∙ Salis, H.M.
    A portable expression resource for engineering cross-species genetic circuits and pathways
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:7832
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In the original UBER framework, T7RNAP production is seeded by upstream basal transcription and further auto-regulated through a positive feedback loop catalyzed by an upstream pT7. To prevent compounding RNAP amplification, a negative feedback loop proportionally produces a TetR repressor to inhibit T7RNAP production. However, this original design was not demonstrated to have inducible activity, a critical criterion for the controlled expression of heterologous biosynthetic pathways that may variably exhibit cytotoxicity in diverse hosts.
    Previous work found that the TIR of the T7RNAP was the primary determinant controlling system output (Kushwaha and Salis, 2015

    Kushwaha, M. ∙ Salis, H.M.

    PubMed

    ), thus being suitable for this application. We constructed 16 variants of this circuit that alter the strength of positive-negative feedback, riboswitch variant, and general architecture (Figures 3J and 3K; Data S2). These variants were initially tested in E. coli Mach1 cells on a low-copy miniRK2 vector pT7RNAP (Figure S4B). The output is measured with a GFP reporter on a second plasmid, pT7 GFP (Figure S4C). Although T7RNAP transcribed by seeding transcription alone (variant T0) was active, the signal became highly attenuated when we tested two theophylline riboswitch variants (T1 and T2) (Figure 3L). This attenuation was rescued by adding positive feedback (T3); however, this came at the cost of high uninduced background expression. Adding negative feedback (T4 and T5) substantially reduced the background without compromising the induced expression level. Positive feedback strength was adjusted by comparing the wildtype pT7WT with an attenuated mutant pT7H9 (Jones et al., 2015
    54.
    Jones, J.A. ∙ Vernacchio, V.R. ∙ Lachance, D.M. ...
    ePathOptimize: a combinatorial approach for transcriptional balancing of metabolic pathways
    Sci. Rep. 2015; 5:11301
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Figure 3M); this did not significantly affect the reporter activity. Additionally, tetR and T7RNAP genes were codon optimized, also without any significant impact on expression levels (T12 and T13). A significant increase in dynamic range was observed when the T7RNAP and tetR genes were split from a bicistronic operon to a two-gene architecture (T15). This change removed the tetR gene from direct negative feedback, likely explaining the stronger background repression in the uninduced state. To benchmark this circuit, we transformed the pT7-eGFP plasmid into E. coli BL21(DE3), where T7RNAP is produced by an isopropyl β- d-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG)-induced placUV5 promoter. Compared with BL21(DE3), variant T15 maintained equally induced expression (non-significant difference), with 66-fold lower uninduced background than BL21(DE3) (p < 0.0001). We demonstrated that variant T15 functions as an AND gate, requiring both theophylline and anhydrotetracycline (aTc) for full induction (Figure 3N). We found that higher levels of induction impair growth (Figure 3O), highlighting the importance of titratable expression.
    To assess whether this T7RNAP gene circuit can function in both Gram-negative and -positive strains, we placed variant T15 and the eGFP reporter onto an ultra-broad host-range shuttle vector, consisting of the RSF1010 (mobAY25F) (Bishé et al., 2019

    Development of chromosomal-integrated landing pads for SGE mobilization

    To complement the plasmid-based mobilization approach, we sought to develop a chromosomal integration strategy for the stable transfer of SGEs across diverse hosts, given that previous studies have demonstrated that integration can increase genetic stability and biosynthetic pathway productivity (Tyo et al., 2009
    124.
    Tyo, K.E.J. ∙ Ajikumar, P.K. ∙ Stephanopoulos, G.

    We tested an apramycin selectable landing pad, where seed transcription for the T7RNAP circuit was provided either by the active, broad host-range promoter P1 from pIP1433 (Trieu-Cuot et al., 1985
    122.
    Trieu-Cuot, P. ∙ Gerbaud, G. ∙ Lambert, T. ...
    In vivo transfer of genetic information between gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria
    EMBO J. 1985; 4:3583-3587
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)

    ; Figure S5) or by relying on background transcription at the host integration locus. Upon mobilizing this landing pad into E. coli MG1655 (transconjugation frequency = 1.5 × 10−5), we used flow cytometry to evaluate the transposed population ± T7RNAP circuit induction (n ∼ 2,000 clones). The resulting population had broad fluorescence distributions evidenced by an elevated coefficient of variation (CV) (Figure 4C), suggesting that there were context effects caused by the integration locus. We evaluated four individual clones by flow cytometry and observed heterogeneity at several levels, including lower uninduced background fluorescence (Clone 1) and higher induction strength (Clone 3). This approach allows us to leverage genetic context as a variable for tuning heterologous expression by selecting clones possessing the desired profile. By surveying multiple genetic loci, we identified a “privileged” clone (Clone 3), which upon theophylline induction, showed 20-fold stronger GFP expression than the population average. This variability emerged in landing pads that both contained and lacked the pIP1433 seeding promoter (Figure 4D), indicating that the presence of a strong promoter at the 5′ edge of the landing pad did not preclude heterogeneity caused by the integration locus.
    To determine whether this strategy works in diverse microbes, we tested our conjugation-transposition system on a selected number of Gammaproteobacterial clades—Klebsiella aerogenes, Salmonella enterica, Pseudomonas putida, and Pseudomonas veronii, which exhibited transconjugation frequencies of 1.6 × 10−5, 9.2 × 10−8, 4.4 × 10−7, and 2.1 × 10−7, respectively. Upon transposition, we selected seven random clones to assay for inducible GFP production. We consistently found that within each strain, individual clones differ in the levels of GFP expression in response to theophylline induction (Figure 4D). These data demonstrate locus-specific variability of gene expression and the ability to screen loci to control expression levels across strains.
    To introduce pathways into the landing pad, SGEs were cloned into an R6K-based suicide vector, pPath (Figure S4G), containing the phiC31 integrase and an aminoglycoside resistance gene functional in prokaryotes (kanamycin) and S. cerevisiae (G418). Pathways were flanked by asymmetrical attB sites, allowing integrase-mediated site-specific integration of the SGE cargo into the landing pad, displacing the GFP-luciferase reporter (Figure 4B). To test functionality, we introduced an SGE for the biosynthesis of the purple pigment violacein, natively produced by Chromobacterium violaceum (Kumar, 2012

    ; Figure 4E). First, we quantified the consequences of redesigning this pathway into an SGE using our CAD-SGE algorithm. We compared the native wildtype pathway sequence with one where transcription is driven by pT7 and with a fully redesigned SGE. To guide the selection of yeast promoter strength in the SGE, we used previous metabolic engineering literature, which suggested that vioA and vioC should be expressed more strongly than the other three genes (Jones et al., 2015
    54.
    Jones, J.A. ∙ Vernacchio, V.R. ∙ Lachance, D.M. ...
    ePathOptimize: a combinatorial approach for transcriptional balancing of metabolic pathways
    Sci. Rep. 2015; 5:11301

    Scopus (0)

    ). In the heterologous host P. putida, we found that the wild-type sequence poorly produced pigment, compared with the pigment production by native C. violaceum (Figure 4F). Natively, transcription is regulated by a strain-specific quorum sensing mechanism (McClean et al., 1997
    80.
    McClean, K.H. ∙ Winson, M.K. ∙ Fish, L. ...

Pigment production with the SGE, which was induced with 1 mM theophylline + 100 ng/mL aTc, was 8-fold over the wild-type pathway in P. putida (p < 0.001) and 2-fold over that of C. violaceum (p < 0.05). Production of the pigment could be titrated through the addition of theophylline (Figure 4F). Pigment production was highest at 10 mM theophylline in P. putida, while peaking at 1 mM in K. aerogenes and S. enterica. By measuring the final OD660 of induced strains, we found that the latter strains are less fit at high induction concentrations. Collectively, this highlights the importance of titratable induction as a method to mitigate toxicity and strain-to-strain variations in optimal expression levels (Figure 4G).

    Characterization of a human commensal biosynthetic pathway using CAD-SGE technology

    To functionally apply this system for natural product discovery, we targeted an uncharacterized BGC that had previously been computationally predicted (Donia et al., 2014
    36.
    Donia, M.S. ∙ Cimermancic, P. ∙ Schulze, C.J. ...
    A systematic analysis of biosynthetic gene clusters in the human microbiome reveals a common family of antibiotics
    Cell. 2014; 158:1402-1414
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (423)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) from the genome of Lactobacillus iners LEAF 2052A-d, which was isolated from the vagina of a bacterial vaginosis patient (cataloged as “BGC08”). The predicted gene cluster, which we refer to as the tyrocitabine (tyb) pathway, was initially annotated to contain a nonribosomal peptide synthetase (tybD), a regulatory gene, a major facilitator family drug transporter (tybA), and several genes of unknown function. BLAST and InterPro searches allowed us to additionally predict tRNA synthetase (tybB), ribosyltransferase (tybC), and (de)hydrogenase (tybE) functions for the unknown genes. Domain analysis of the predicted nonribosomal peptide synthetase (NRPS) indicated a single adenylation (A) domain, a peptidyl- or acyl-carrier protein thiolation domain (T), an incomplete condensation (C) domain, and a fourth domain of unknown function. Analysis of the tRNA synthetase suggested homology to Class Ic TyrRS; however, it lacked the C-terminal RNA binding domain of canonical tRNA synthetases (Pang et al., 2014
    92.
    Pang, Y.L.J. ∙ Poruri, K. ∙ Martinis, S.A.
    tRNA synthetase: tRNA aminoacylation and beyond
    Wiley Interdiscip. Rev. RNA. 2014; 5:461-480
    Crossref
    Scopus (96)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We chose to characterize this pathway because of the human disease pathology of the source strain, the presence of a transporter gene that suggests the product is secreted, and the unexpected participation of a tRNA synthetase. In our cloning, we included a closely situated downstream gene of unknown function, as well as the native phosphopantetheinyl transferase (PPTase) gene located elsewhere in the genome, which would facilitate NRPS post-translational activation. The upstream transcriptional regulator gene was omitted for SGE design (Figure 5A). As done for the violacein pathway, we compared the native wild-type pathway sequence with the one with orthogonal pT7 transcription and with a fully redesigned SGE (Figure 5A). To compare experiments conducted with the violacein pathway, the orphan constructs were first mobilized into the landing pad-domesticated P. putida host for initial metabolite analysis.
    Through pathway-targeted metabolite analysis, based on high-performance liquid chromatography quadrupole-time of-flight mass spectrometry (HPLC-QTOF-MS), we initially focused on two of the most highly abundant pathway-dependent ions (m/z 314.1195 and m/z 627.1771). Introducing the wildtype pathway sequence into P. putida led to only trace amounts of the m/z 314 metabolite, and we were unable to detect quantifiable amounts of the m/z 627 metabolite (Figure 5B). Complementation with pT7 transcription was unable to rescue metabolite production, suggesting post-transcriptional regulation. The wild-type sequence contains a low GC content of 27.7%, suggesting possible maladaptive codon usage. Importantly, the fully redesigned SGE, which accounts for multiple layers of regulation, successfully rescued metabolite production in P. putida (Figure 5B).
    To further interrogate the biosynthesis of this pathway, we used E. coli BL21(DE3) to perform detailed reverse genetic analysis and scale up production of intermediates and products for isolation and characterization. Twelve pathway-dependent entities (i.e., (M+H) m/z 394.0858 phospho-tyrolose [1], 314.1195 tyrolose [2], 316.1352 tyrolitol [3], 627.1771 tyrocitabine-626 [4)], 669.1877 acyl-tyrocitabine-668 [5ab], 697.2190 acyl-tyrocitabine-696 [6ab], 725.2503 acyl-tyrocitabine-724 [7ab], and 753.2816 acyl-tyrocitabine-752 [8ab]) were characterized (Data S3). UV and multidimensional nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analyses and comparison with a synthetic standard revealed the structure of 2 to be a ribosylated tyrosine that had undergone an Amadori rearrangement. 3 was a reduced form of 2 and was similarly confirmed using a synthetic standard (reductive amination of L-Tyr and D-arabinose). MS/MS fragmentation analysis and molecular formula assignment of 4 suggested that this compound could be generated via an adenylation-rearrangement sequence of the tyrolitol-type substrate(s) (Figure 5C). NMR experiments on tyrocitabine remarkably established the presence of AMP and an orthoester-phosphate-type motif as two key structural building blocks. The connectivity of these two moieties was established via a 1D 31P NMR decoupling experiment. The 3D structure of the intriguing ring system in 4 constructed by the orthoester-phosphate moiety was confirmed by the comparison of experimental interproton distances calibrated from ROESY with those from a computational simulation of plausible diastereomers. The remaining pathway-dependent entities (5a/b, 6a/b, 7a/b, 8a/b) were structurally related to 4 with varying acyl modifications, including acetylation, butyrylation, hexanoylation, and octanoylation, respectively. ROESY and heteronuclear multiple bond correlation (HMBC) NMR analyses confirmed that these acyl chains were substituted at the 3′ position (major, a series) of the AMP ribosyl moiety with some observed spontaneous intramolecular transesterification to the 2′ position (minor, b series).
    Single-gene deletions of the multigene pathway in E. coli (Figure 5C) supported an order of operations in tyrocitabine assembly (Figure 5D). These studies support a step-wise biosynthesis in which the anthranilate phosphoribosyltransferase-family ribosyltransferase (tybC) is required for the ribosylation of L-Tyr and the subsequent Amadori rearrangement leading to phospho-tyrolose (1) and tyrolose (2). This mechanism is reminiscent of intermediate steps in bacterial tryptophan and histidine biosynthesis (Barona-Gómez and Hodgson, 2003
    8.
    Barona-Gómez, F. ∙ Hodgson, D.A.
    Occurrence of a putative ancient-like isomerase involved in histidine and tryptophan biosynthesis
    EMBO Rep. 2003; 4:296-300
    Crossref
    Scopus (72)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We found that the (de)hydrogenase (tybE) contributes to tyrolitol (3) formation, suggesting that TybE hydrogenates the tyrolose precursor(s). The tRNA synthetase (tybB) is required for a remarkable “abortive” tRNA synthetase reaction, leading to tyrocitabine, the free adenylated product 4 featuring an orthoester linkage at the phosphate moiety, suggesting an evolutionary selection for the loss of traditional tRNA synthetase functionality in favor of specialized metabolite biosynthesis. Orthoesters appear in a variety of natural products, but their biosyntheses remain largely unknown (Li et al., 2018
    70.
    Li, S. ∙ Zhang, J. ∙ Liu, Y. ...
    Direct genetic and enzymatic evidence for oxidative cyclization in hygromycin B biosynthesis
    ACS Chem. Biol. 2018; 13:2203-2210
    Crossref
    Scopus (8)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Matsuda et al., 2018
    78.
    Matsuda, Y. ∙ Bai, T. ∙ Phippen, C.B.W. ...
    Novofumigatonin biosynthesis involves a non-heme iron-dependent endoperoxide isomerase for orthoester formation
    Nat. Commun. 2018; 9:2587
    Crossref
    Scopus (42)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Acylation of 4 to access major 5a–8a required the tybD NRPS gene, suggesting that the NRPS plays an acyl-ligase role in bridging fatty acid and nucleotide biosynthesis.
    To confirm the biosynthetic route, we conducted in vitro protein biochemical studies using individually purified enzymes and substrate feeding studies in E. coli expressing the tyb pathway (tyb+). We first established that isolated TybC uses L-Tyr and PRPP as a ribosyl donor to produce the Amadori rearrangement products 1 and 2 (Figure 6A). Next, we demonstrated that TybE catalyzes a stereoselective hydrogenation of both 1 and 2 into phospho-3 and 3, respectively (Figure 6B). However, phospho-3 was not detected in cell extracts from tyb+ E. coli, suggesting early phosphate hydrolysis in cells. L-Tyr supplementation in tyb+ E. coli enhanced the production of 2 (Figure S6A), consistent with TybC’s proposed Amadori synthase role. Moreover, supplementation with synthetic 2 enhanced the production of 4 in tyb+ E. coli and was capable of “chemically complementing” a knockout of the ribosyltransferase tybC. These studies strongly support the intermediacy of 2 (Figures S5B and S5C). We further demonstrated that isolated TybB could directly transform the polyol-amino acid 3 into the orthoester-phosphate 4 in an ATP-dependent manner (Figure 6C), confirming the “abortive” tRNA synthetase role of this tRNA synthetase family. Finally, feeding free fatty acids, such as octanoic acid, to tyb+ E. coli significantly enhanced the production of the ultimate NRPS-dependent acyl-tyrocitabines (Figure S6D).
    To establish a biological activity for the tryocitabine family, we used the similarity ensemble approach (SEA) (Keiser et al., 2007
    57.
    Keiser, M.J. ∙ Roth, B.L. ∙ Armbruster, B.N. ...
    Relating protein pharmacology by ligand chemistry
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2007; 25:197-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (1349)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to computationally predict candidate targets, and various components of protein translation were among the hits (Data S4). Using PURExpress protein synthesis technologies (Shimizu et al., 2001
    110.
    Shimizu, Y. ∙ Inoue, A. ∙ Tomari, Y. ...
    Cell-free translation reconstituted with purified components
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2001; 19:751-755
    Crossref
    Scopus (1292)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to probe the molecular mechanism, we established that 4 inhibited the translation of a GFP reporter with a half-maximal inhibition (IC50) of 13 μM, which was comparable to an erythromycin control (IC50 2 μM) (Figure 6D). This inhibition occurred with either DNA or RNA substrates, suggesting that inhibition in the in vitro system was largely occurring at the post-transcriptional level (Figures S7A and S7B). Interestingly, the activity was abrogated when tyrocitabine was acylated, suggesting a possible prodrug mechanism where the acylated molecules would require hydrolytic activation by esterases in the recipient organism(s) (Figure S7C).
    To test the host range, we mobilized the SGE into various bacteria (E. coli MG1655, K. aerogenes, P. putida, B. subtilis, and S. enterica) and S. cerevisiae. We found that our SGE can successfully produce the bioactive tyrocitabine (4) in all strains. The relative abundances of the tyrocitabines and their intermediates varied, suggesting anticipated strain-specific differences in metabolic flux through the pathway (Figure 7A). We found the P. putida host to be particularly gifted at producing the largest molecule acyl-tyrocitabine-752 (8), as assessed by relative HPLC-QTOF-MS analysis. By contrast, tyrocitabine and its precursors, but not the acyl-tyrocitabines, were detected in B. subtilis or S. cerevisiae. This diversity of outcomes highlights the utility of our approach in enabling rapid dissemination of genetic material across numerous strains belonging to broad taxonomic groups. Attempts to detect and induce the production of the tyrocitabines in the native Lactobacillus iners LEAF 2052A-d failed to detect pathway-dependent metabolites beyond tyrolose (2) under the conditions of our studies (Figures S6D and S6E), highlighting the importance of employing a robust strategy to elucidate this pathway in heterologous hosts.
    To analyze the broader phylogenetic distribution of this class of molecules, we performed amino acid BLAST homology searches of TybB against microbial genome sequences hosted on JGI-IMG, finding ∼100 close hits (1 × 10−5 E value cutoff), which were largely distributed across Firmicutes and Actinobacteria (Figure 7B; Data S5). 92 of these hits were clustered with at least one other biosynthetic enzyme. To identify homologs at a gene cluster level and provide secondary support, we performed a search using cBlaster, binning on clusters that contained at least two genes with at least 20% amino acid similarity to proteins encoded in the Lactobacillus iners tyb pathway (Data S5) (Gilchrist et al., 2021
    43.
    Gilchrist, C.L.M. ∙ Booth, T.J. ∙ van Wersch, B. ...
    cblaster: a remote search tool for rapid identification and visualization of homologous gene clusters
    Bioinformatics Adv. 2021; 1
    vbab016
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Although the resulting hits largely overlapped, cBlaster identified additional hits among archaeal species, suggesting cross-domain transfer of this pathway. These hits, like TybB, resembled Class 1c tRNA synthetases but lacked an RNA binding domain, as predicted by InterPro (Figure 7C). We found hits annotated as both TrpRS and TyrRS, suggesting potential differences in amino acid substrate specificity. Interestingly, these annotated “tRNA synthetases” were encoded in highly diversified operon contexts. Among the various operons (24 illustrated in Figure 7B), the common feature was the presence of the TybC-like ribosyltransferase, but co-localizing accessory genes ranged from predicted NRPSs to hydrolases, glycosyltransferases, (de)hydrogenases, methyltransferases, and radical SAM enzymes. Notably, several operons contained multiple Class Ic synthetase-like enzymes in tandem, both lacking RNA binding domains. Based on our proposed biosynthetic route of the tyrocitabines and observation of various accessory enzymes in the related uncharacterized pathways, these data suggest that the tyrocitabines represent the founding members of a much broader class of specialized nucleotide metabolites and motivate further investigation in future studies.

    Discussion

    In this study, we developed foundational technologies that allow us to decouple specialized metabolite BGCs from native layers of regulation, redesigning them into SGEs with versatile cross-kingdom functionality and permitting their transfer into diverse species. Together, these advances enabled the redesign of biosynthetic pathways and their expression in diverse microbes for the discovery of a class of nucleotide metabolites from the human microbiome. This work complements and advances current heterologous expression approaches, unifying the utility of genetic refactoring (Ajikumar et al., 2010

    ) tend to be strong constitutive promoters with variable activity across strains. Other canonical titratable promoters, such as pTet and pLac, which, while widely used in E. coli, are largely inactive in Bacillus and require strain-specific sequence optimization (Geissendörfer and Hillen, 1990
    41.
    Geissendörfer, M. ∙ Hillen, W.

    ).
    Redesigned SGEs are amenable to rapid metabolic flux optimizations using computational guided flux balance analysis methods (Orth et al., 2010
    88.
    Orth, J.D. ∙ Thiele, I. ∙ Palsson, B.Ø.
    What is flux balance analysis?

    ) or multiplex genome editing technologies (Anzalone et al., 2020
    5.
    Anzalone, A.V. ∙ Koblan, L.W. ∙ Liu, D.R.
    Genome editing with CRISPR-Cas nucleases, base editors, transposases and prime editors

    Scopus (581)

    ; Wannier et al., 2021
    133.
    Wannier, T.M. ∙ Ciaccia, P.N. ∙ Ellington, A.D. ...
    Recombineering and MAGE
    Nat. Rev. Methods Primers. 2021; 1:8
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Predictable tuning of gene expression is achievable in diverse hosts by modulating 5′ UTRs or adding or removing 10-mer UTRs in the eukaryotic promoters. Importantly, strains domesticated with a landing pad can be used “off the shelf” for future heterologous expression of BGCs, other pathways, or other genetic elements of interest.
    Our approach overcame two key challenges when applied for the discovery of the tyrocitabines. First, without redesigning into an SGE, we were unable to detect metabolites beyond the early intermediate 2 in P. putida, which would have prevented the complete elucidation and characterization of the L. iners BGC. Similarly, attempts to detect the tyrocitabines in the native Lactobacillus iners LEAF 2052a-D failed under the conditions of our studies (Figures 5D and 5E), highlighting the necessity for heterologous expression. Second, the ability to mobilize the deorphanized pathway across multiple hosts simultaneously allowed us to quickly identify productive heterologous hosts. For example, we observed that the activity of the largest enzyme (the NRPS TybD) in the pathway was a bottleneck in several strains, causing the pathway to stall at tryrocitabine (4). Ultimately, our findings highlight the utility of being able to survey many distant hosts simultaneously, an observation consistent with previous studies (Wang et al., 2019a
    129.
    Wang, G. ∙ Zhao, Z. ∙ Ke, J. ...
    CRAGE enables rapid activation of biosynthetic gene clusters in undomesticated bacteria
    Nat. Microbiol. 2019; 4:2498-2510
    Crossref
    Scopus (51)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    Additionally, we propose that the tyrocitabines represent the founding members of a much larger, yet previously elusive, class of specialized microbial nucleotide metabolites in the environment, including members of the human microbiome. Specifically, we found numerous instances of misannotated Class Ic tRNA synthetases lacking RNA binding domains and co-localizing with anthranilate phosphoribosyltransferase-like enzymes in both bacteria and archaea. Accessory proteins diverge substantially in the BGCs. We also found pathways that contain two tandem, yet sequence distinct Class Ic tRNA synthetases, homologous to TrpRS and TyrRS, similarly lacking their RNA binding domains. This suggests the core tyrocitabine scaffold is potentially highly diversified in nature. This structural diversity could have profound implications on the cell type specificity, localization, and biological targets of the resulting functionalized molecules. Although conservation and colocalization of key enzymatic components invite the hypothesis that the core tyrocitabine scaffold may be present in homologous pathways, further work will be needed to screen this chemical diversity and assess the extent to which the scaffold is maintained.
    Noncanonical tRNA synthetase activities are of increasing interest. For instance, human TrpRS (i.e., WARS) has been implicated in playing key roles in innate immunity and p53 and IFNγ signaling (Jin, 2019
    53.
    Jin, M.
    Unique roles of tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase in immune control and its therapeutic implications

    58.
    Kim, C.S. ∙ Gatsios, A. ∙ Cuesta, S. ...
    Characterization of autoinducer-3 structure and biosynthesis in E. coli
    ACS Cent. Sci. 2020; 6:197-206
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)

    ). Overall, the dedicated abortive tRNA synthetase reactions discovered in this study add a distinct dimension to specialized nucleotide metabolism, prompting further structural and biological characterization. More broadly, this highlights a largely unexplored genome mining strategy—scrutinizing (misannotated) genes that are classically considered “central metabolism” and filtering for those with missing or added domains and unusual genome context. Such an approach could uncover the continual evolution and repurposing of otherwise ancestral genes for acquiring new functions and biochemistries, including the discovery of non-standard amino acids (Arranz-Gibert et al., 2018
    6.
    Arranz-Gibert, P. ∙ Vanderschuren, K. ∙ Isaacs, F.J.
    Next-generation genetic code expansion
    Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2018; 46:203-211

    ).
    In this work, we present a synthetic biology technology employed to elucidate orphan BGCs. Given that only ∼103 of ∼105 gene clusters currently predicted on DOE’s IMG database have empirical elucidation, our approach is particularly poised to be scaled toward the discovery of these uncharacterized BGCs. Beyond this application, we propose that the versatility of our redesign principles can hold broad utility in rapidly domesticating diverse microbes for multiple applications, such as maximizing titers of high-value molecules in heterologous hosts (Cravens et al., 2019
