    ). Through the development of an enabling technology for the design, mobilization, and expression of genetic elements, we anticipate that our work could aid in the domestication of non-model organisms and communities for diverse applications in medicine, environmental sustainability, and biotechnology.

    Limitations of the study

    The scope of this study did not include a screen of the full host range of our technology but instead focused on its development, characterization, and application. In particular, several of our proof-of-concept studies were in model heterologous hosts, such as P. putida. Future efforts, including the dissemination and application of our approach, will expand the range of species tested to include a wider selection of undomesticated and environmental strains to broaden utility and further reductively study the impacts of our gene redesign principles on expression levels and host range. For instance, efforts to examine how robustly our hybrid promoters function in alternate eukaryotic and prokaryotic hosts would be a worthy pursuit. Additionally, the promising bioactivity lead of the tyrocitabines prompts further study of their molecular mechanism in the vaginal microbiome.

    STAR★Methods

    Key resources table

    Resource availability

    Lead contact

    Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the lead contact, Farren Isaacs (farren.isaacs@yale.edu).

    Materials availability

    Plasmids generated in this study have will be available on Addgene at https://www.addgene.org/Farren_Isaacs/. This study did not generate additional new unique reagents.

    Experimental model and subject details

    Microbial strains

    Please refer to key resources table and Data S2 for the complete list.

    Method details

    Media

    Cultures of E. coli and B. subtilis were maintained in Luria broth (10 g/L Tryptone, 5 g/L NaCl, 5 g/L yeast extract) at 37 °C. Cultures of K. aerogenes, P. putida, P. veronii, and S. enterica were maintained in Luria broth at 30 °C. Cultures of S. cerevisiae were maintained in YPD medium (10 g/L yeast extract, 20 g/L peptone, 20 g/L dextrose) at 30 °C. When antibiotic selection was required, kanamycin was used at 10 ug/mL in B. subtilis and 35 ug/mL in other strains, chloramphenicol was used at 5 ug/mL in B. subtilis and 12.5 ug/mL in other strains, apramycin was used at 10 ug/mL in B. subtilis and 50 ug/mL in other strains, hygromycin B was used at 200 ug/mL in S. cerevisiae, G418 was used at 200 ug/mL in S. cerevisiae, and spectinomycin was used at 95 ug/mL in E. coli. For inductions, theophylline stock solution was prepared at 50 mM in water, anhydrotetracycline (aTc) was prepared as 100 ug/mL in 100% ethanol.

    Single gene knockouts from biosynthetic pathways

    E. coli EcNR1, which contains lambda red recombineering machinery integrated at the bioAB locus (Wang et al., 2009
    130.
    Wang, H.H. ∙ Isaacs, F.J. ∙ Carr, P.A. ...
    Programming cells by multiplex genome engineering and accelerated evolution
    Nature. 2009; 460:894-898
    Crossref
    Scopus (1121)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), was used to perform single gene knockouts within the BGC08 pathway. To support the plasmid backbone, we used recombineering to insert the R6K pir gene at a noncoding chromosomal locus (coordinate: 1,415,470). To avoid adding additional antibiotic resistance burden, we used the tolC dual selectable marker to perform all manipulations – this marker can be selected for with 0.005% SDS, and against with colicin E1 (DeVito, 2008
    35.
    DeVito, J.A.
    Recombineering with tolC as a selectable/counter-selectable marker: remodeling the rRNA operons of Escherichia coli
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2008; 36:e4
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We deleted the native tolC locus and reintroduced this marker to replace the ORF of individual genes in BGC08. Generally, for gene insertions, cassettes were amplified by PCR (Kapa HiFi Polymerase) using primers that appended 50 bp homology arms to the target. Cells were grown in LB at 34 °C until OD600 of 0.6, then heat shocked in a 42 °C shaking water bath for 15 minutes. Cells were immediately placed on ice and 1 mL aliquots were washed 2x with ice-cold ddH2O and resuspended in 50 uL ddH2O + 100 ng DNA template, before transferring to a 1 mm electrocuvette. Cells were pulsed at 1800 V, 25 uF, 200 Ω (Bio-rad GenePulser) and recovered in 3 mL LB for 3 hours before plating on selective medium. For deleting tolC, a similar procedure was used, but with the template being a 5′-phosphorothioated 90 mer oligonucleotide containing 45 bp homology arms to the deletion locus.

    Plasmid construction

    All plasmids (see also Data S2) created for this study were constructed via Gibson assembly (NEB). Native biosynthetic pathways for violacein and BGC08/tyrocitabine were PCR amplified from the gDNA of C. violeceum ATCC 12472 and L. iners LEAF2052A-d, respectively. Redesigned biosynthetic pathways were sourced as overlapping synthetic DNA fragments <3.2 kb in size. Both were cloned into the pPath integrating shuttle vector (linearized with the restriction enzyme SfiI) via Gibson assembly, and transformed into E. coli TransforMax™ EC100D™ pir+ cells (Lucigen) for maintenance. Selection was performed with 5% sucrose to select against the parental plasmid.

    Transformation conditions

    For E. coli, electroporation was used to transform plasmid constructs. Briefly, 1 mL mid-log cell culture was washed 2x in 10% ice-cold glycerol, concentrated to 50 uL, and loaded into a 1 mm electrocuvette and pulsed at 1800 V, 25 uF, 200 Ω (Bio-rad GenePulser). For B. subtilis, natural transformation was used. Briefly, a single colony was picked into 1 mL transformation medium (900 uL ddH2O, 100 uL 10x MMC, 3 mM MgSO4). The culture was grown at 37 °C for 4 hours. To each 200 uL aliquot of culture, 100 ng DNA was added and grown further for 2 hours before plating on selective LB medium. 10x MMC stock solution consisted of (10.7 g K2HPO4, 5.2 g KH2PO4, 20 g glucose, 0.88 g sodium citrate, 2.2 g potassium glutamate, 1 ml 1000X ferric ammonium citrate (2.2% stock), and 1 g casein hydrolysate raised to 100 mL final volume with ddH20). For S. cerevisiae, the Frozen-EZ Yeast Transformation II Kit (Zymo) was used. For other bacterial strains used in this study, landing pads and biosynthetic pathways were introduced via conjugation.

    Conjugation

    For conjugation, the donor strain used was E. coli BW19851 (Yale Coli Genetic Stock Center), which contains the incP RP4 conjugative machinery and chromosomally-integrated R6K pir replication gene. We further used lambda red recombineering via the pORTMAGE protocol (Nyerges et al., 2016
    87.
    Nyerges, Á. ∙ Csörgő, B. ∙ Nagy, I. ...
    A highly precise and portable genome engineering method allows comparison of mutational effects across bacterial species
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2016; 113:2502-2507
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to knock out the asd gene with apramycin resistance, which produced a diaminopimelic acid (DAP) auxotroph for post-conjugation counterselection. This strain was also transformed in the pInh to minimize the expression of transposase and integrase activity. Interspecies conjugations were performed by mixing 1 mL late log donor and recipient strains, washing away selective antibiotics with PBS, concentrating the mixture 10x, and spotting onto solid LB + 30 ug/mL DAP, overlayed with a 0.45 uM nitrocellulose filter (Millipore). Conjugations proceeded for 6 hours, after which the filter paper was removed, bacteria resuspended in LB medium, and plated on selective DAP-free medium.

    Prediction of RNA secondary structure at N-terminus

    To predict RNA secondary structure across open reading frames, we calculated the minimum folding energy across each CDS using a 30 bp sliding window with the Vienna RNA Suite. To construct plots, for each nucleotide position, the folding energy was averaged across all analyzed genes. Here, to avoid the confounding variable of translational coupling, we limited analysis to a test set of genes that did not overlap with upstream CDSs (n=464).

    Prediction of prokaryotic transcriptional terminators

    The program TranstermHP (Kingsford et al., 2007
    59.
    Kingsford, C.L. ∙ Ayanbule, K. ∙ Salzberg, S.L.
    Rapid, accurate, computational discovery of Rho-independent transcription terminators illuminates their relationship to DNA uptake
    Genome Biol. 2007; 8:R22
    Crossref
    Scopus (370)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used to predict rho-independent transcriptional terminators on both strands. Default parameters for stem-loop and tail scoring were used. The confidence threshold for calling a terminator was left as >76.

    Calculation of prokaryotic ribosome binding site thermodynamic predictions

    For RBS strength predictions, thermodynamic parameters were calculated in accordance with (Salis et al., 2009
    102.
    Salis, H.M. ∙ Mirsky, E.A. ∙ Voigt, C.A.
    Automated design of synthetic ribosome binding sites to control protein expression
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2009; 27:946-950
    Crossref
    Scopus (1220)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). This calculation is summarized as:
    Δ⁢𝐺𝑡⁢𝑜⁢𝑡=Δ⁢𝐺𝑚⁢𝑅⁢𝑁⁢𝐴:𝑟⁢𝑅⁢𝑁⁢𝐴+Δ⁢𝐺𝑠⁢𝑡⁢𝑎⁢𝑟⁢𝑡+Δ⁢𝐺𝑠⁢𝑝⁢𝑎⁢𝑐⁢𝑖⁢𝑛⁢𝑔−Δ⁢𝐺𝑠⁢𝑡⁢𝑎⁢𝑛⁢𝑑⁢𝑏⁢𝑦−Δ⁢𝐺𝑚⁢𝑅⁢𝑁⁢𝐴
    This Gibbs free energy calculation above is converted to a predicted translation initiation rate(TIR), simplified as:
    𝑇⁢𝐼⁢𝑅=𝐴−𝛽⁡(Δ⁢𝐺𝑡⁢𝑜⁢𝑡)
    where β = 0.45, and A = 2,500.
    To collect the Gibbs Free Energy values, the Vienna RNA Suite was used (Lorenz et al., 2011
    75.
    Lorenz, R. ∙ Bernhart, S.H. ∙ Höner zu Siederdissen, C. ...
    ViennaRNA package 2.0
    Algorithms Mol. Biol. 2011; 6:26
    Crossref
    Scopus (2441)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The following assumptions were made: the relevant mRNA considered was +/- 35 bp flanking the start codon. The ribosome was assumed to unfold the first 15 bp of the ORF. The standby site was 4 bp upstream of the rRNA binding site, and the relevant anti-Shine Dalgarno rRNA sequence considered was the terminal 9 bp of 16S rRNA (for E. coli, this sequence is “ACCUCCUUA”). The Δ⁢𝐺𝑠⁢𝑡⁢𝑎⁢𝑟⁢𝑡 values used were: “AUG”:-1.194, “GUG”:-0.0748, “UUG”:-0.0435, “CUG”:-0.03406. To account for multiple mRNA:rRNA folding configuration possibilities, we used the RNAduplex program to duplex the rRNA to the region of the mRNA 3-13 bp upstream of the start codon. All possible duplexes +/- 1.5 kcal/mol of the MFE were considered; for each possible duplex, Δ⁢𝐺𝑡⁢𝑜⁢𝑡 was calculated. The duplex that minimized Δ⁢𝐺𝑡⁢𝑜⁢𝑡 was considered the equilibrium translation initiation configuration.

    Construction of yeast promoter library

    Yeast promoters (see also Data S1) were constructed from individual modular components. “Core” and “UAS” sequences were sourced from previous literature (Redden and Alper, 2015
    96.
    Redden, H. ∙ Alper, H.S.
    The development and characterization of synthetic minimal yeast promoters
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:7810
    Crossref
    Scopus (151)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Spacer sequences were constructed by creating random 30 mers (that lacked NTG sequences to prevent internal start codons) and surveying for a lack of transcription factor binding sites derived from the YeastTract database (Monteiro et al., 2020
    81.
    Monteiro, P.T. ∙ Oliveira, J. ∙ Pais, P. ...
    YEASTRACT+: a portal for cross-species comparative genomics of transcription regulation in yeasts
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2020; 48:D642-D649
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Transcription start site sites were pulled from the native S. cerevisiae genome, binning for sites that had been empirically validated with SAGE experiments and contained the canonical yeast transcription start site motif (Zhang and Dietrich, 2005
    139.
    Zhang, Z. ∙ Dietrich, F.S.
    Mapping of transcription start sites in Saccharomyces cerevisiae using 5′ SAGE
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2005; 33:2838-2851
    Crossref
    Scopus (148)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Yeast promoters were combinatorially assembled, ensuring that no permutation of three UASs was repeated in the library to minimize sequence similarity, and no spacer or TSS sequence is reused. Each promoter was scanned with the RBS predictor to highlight potential start sites, which were iteratively removed by altering spacer sequences. To deplete nucleosome occupancy, NuPoP was used to predict nucleosome occupancy. Each promoter was specifically assayed for the probability of nucleosome occupancy at the TATA box and TSS. 5 mer poly A or poly T sequences were added to spacers until nucleosome occupancy fell below 20% probability at both sites. To terminate any unexpected translation initiation from inside the promoter sequence, promoters are flanked with a three-frame stop codon (TAANTAANTAA). Promoters were additionally scanned for rho-independent transcription termination using TransTermHP.

    GFP variant library for codon usage impact analysis

    To collect data presented in Figure S1, the open reading frame of the eGFP gene was recoded to test 8 conditions: 1) using the base codon distribution of E. coli highly expressed genes; 2) using the base codon distribution of B. subtilis highly expressed genes; 3) using a neutral base codon distribution where codons are selected fully randomly; 4) using a base codon distribution enriched in inhibitory codons TTA, AGG, CTA, and CGA; 5) sequences enriched in internal predicted RBS sequences (using E. coli base codon distribution); 6) sequences enriched in predicted internal transcription terminators (using E. coli base codon distribution); 7) sequences with the N-terminal 12 residues consisting of codons enriched in E. coli highly expressed genes; and 8) sequences with the N-terminal 12 residues consisting of FACSseq-enriched codons from Goodman et al. Science 2013. For conditions 1-6, the N-terminal 36bp sequence was fixed. For conditions 7-8, the C terminal (bp 37+) sequence was fixed. For all coditional, the RBS was fixed. For each condition, 12 GFP genes were recoded and synthesized. For testing, recoded GFP genes were cloned into a vector (p15A origin of replication; spectinomycin selection) under the control of a T7 promoter, and transformed into E. coli BL21(DE3). Transformed cells were cultured at 37 °C with 250rpm shaking. At OD600 0.6, 100μM IPTG was added, and cultures incubated for an additional 6 hours. Single cell fluorescence was measured using a BD FACS Aria cell sorter and quantified with FlowJo software.

    Flow cytometry analysis

    Fluorescent measurements (Figures 4C, 4D, 5B, S1, S3, and S4) were performed with the BD FACS Aria cell sorter. For experiments where higher throughput was needed (Figures 3E–3I), the Stratedigm 8 with a 96 well plate loader was used. For these analyses, cell cultures were grown, induced when necessary at OD600 of 0.6, and cultured for an additional 12 hours. Cells were diluted 1:10 in PBS and loaded onto the instrument. Quantification was done with FlowJo v10. Briefly, the cell population was gated with the forward scatter and side scatter channels, before quantifying fluorescent intensity in the FITC channel. Across all data sets, to assign a uniform fluorescent Intensity value (as arbitrary units), the raw fluorescent mean value was normalized, via linear scalar, such that the intensity of the cyc1 promoter sample in each data set was “100”.

    Plate reader analysis

    Fluorescent measurements for evaluating the performance of the T7RNAP circuit (Figures 4E–4G, 5 °C) were performed on a BioTek Synergy H1 plate reader. Here, cell cultures were diluted 1:50 into fresh LB + antibiotics. At OD600 0.6, cultures were distributed across a 96 well plate (150 uL per well). As needed, inducers were added and the plate was cultured in a shaking incubator for an additional 12 hours. Cells were pelleted and resuspended in PBS and transferred to a black well clear bottom 96 well plate. OD600 and GFP fluorescence (488 nm ex, 525 nm em) values were measured. To quantify cell density – normalized fluorescence, GFP values were divided by OD600 values. These values were further background subtracted using the average GFP/ OD600 values of wildtype cells.

    Quantification of violacein production

    Violacein pigment was quantified as “Violacein Units” (Blosser and Gray, 2000
    13.
    Blosser, R.S. ∙ Gray, K.M.
    Extraction of violacein from Chromobacterium violaceum provides a new quantitative bioassay for N-acyl homoserine lactone autoinducers
    J. Microbiol. Methods. 2000; 40:47-55
    Crossref
    Scopus (160)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Pigment producing cells were cultured in LB at 30 °C until mid-log optical density. Upon adding relevant inducers, culture was continued at 20 °C for 48 hours. 200 uL of the final culture was diluted in 800 uL PBS to measure OD660nm to quantify cell density. Another 200 uL of the culture was mixed with 200 uL 10% SDS for 5 mins with vortexing. 900 uL butanol was added and vortexed for 5 sec to extract pigment. Samples were pelleted in 1.5 mL tubes at 16000 × g for 5 mins to pellet debris. The top organic layer was collected and Absorbance585nm was measured to quantify violacein content. Violacein units are calculated as:
    𝑉⁢𝑖⁢𝑜⁢𝑙⁢𝑎⁢𝑐⁢𝑒⁢𝑖⁢𝑛𝑈⁢𝑛⁢𝑖⁢𝑡⁢𝑠=𝐴585⁢𝑛⁢𝑚/𝑂⁢𝐷660⁢𝑛⁢𝑚×1000

    Analytical chemistry instrumentation parameters

    Ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) spectra were recorded on an Agilent 1260 Infinity system equipped with a photo diode array (PDA) detector (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA). The full nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy data sets were recorded at 25 °C on an Agilent 600 MHz NMR spectrometer (DD2) equipped with an inverse cold probe (3 mm), employing standard NMR pulse libraries, including 1D 31P (202 MHz) and 1H-31P decoupling experiments. Flash column chromatography was performed on LiChroprep RP18 (40–63 mm, Merck, NJ, USA). High pressure liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS) analysis was conducted on an Agilent 1260 Infinity system using a Phenomenex Luna C18(2) (100 Å) 5 μm (4.6 × 150 mm) (Phenomenex, CA, USA) column or a Hypercarb column (ThermoFisher Scientific Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA, 5 μm, 4.6 × 100 mm) using a PDA detector coupled with a single quadrupole electrospray ionization mass spectrometry instrument (ESI-MS, Agilent 6120). Purification of metabolites addressed in the study was performed using an Agilent Prepstar HPLC system using an Agilent Polaris C18-A 5 μm (21 × 250 mm) column, a Phenomenex Luna C18(2) (100 Å) 10 μm (10 × 250 mm) column, or a Hypercarb column (ThermoFisher Scientific; 5 μm, 10.0 × 250 mm). High-resolution ESI-MS (HR-ESI-MS) data were recorded on an Agilent iFunnel 6550 quadrupole time-of-flight (QTOF) MS instrument fitted with an electrospray ionization (ESI) source linked to an Agilent 1290 Infinity HPLC system with the aforementioned columns. XAD-7 HP resins for metabolite extraction were obtained from ThermoFisher Scientific. NMR data is provided in Data S3.

    Metabolomics-based discovery of pathway-dependent metabolites

    Metabolomics was performed to investigate gene and pathway-dependent metabolites to promote discovery and characterization. For this characterization, we transformed redesigned BGC08 into E. coli BL21(DE3) (this stain was transformed with a plasmid-bound copy of the R6K pir gene to maintain the pPath vector carrying the pathway). A 5 mL LB liquid culture with 50 μg/mL of spectinomycin and 50 μg/mL carbenicillin was prepared as starter cultures by inoculation of single colonies containing either the full pathway, single gene knockouts, or its empty vector, pPath. Upon overnight growth under aerobic conditions (37 °C and 250 rpm), each seed culture (50 μL) was used to inoculate 5 × 5 mL fresh M9 cultures (M9 medium supplemented with 5% casamino acids, 0.2% D-glucose, 1 mM MgSO4, 0.1 mM CaCl2) and incubated (37 °C and 250 rpm) until the OD600 reached 0.8 absorbance units. Cultures were induced with IPTG induction (0.1 mM) on ice and then grown for an additional 48 hours (20 °C and 250 rpm). An M9 medium control was also treated under identical conditions. Cultures were then centrifuged at 14,000 × g (r.t.) for 30 min, XAD-7 HP resins (20 g/L) were added to each clarified supernatant, and the resin-supernatant mixtures were incubated for 2 h at 37 °C and 250 rpm. The filtered resins were then extracted with MeOH (10 mL each), and the extracts were filtered and evaporated under reduced pressure to generate representative crude materials for medium controls, empty vector controls, and full pathway samples. These samples were subjected to HPLC-QTOF-MS analysis followed by comparative metabolomics using Mass Profiler Professional (Agilent Technologies) and methods that we have previously described (Vizcaino et al., 2014
    127.
    Vizcaino, M.I. ∙ Guo, X. ∙ Crawford, J.M.
    Merging chemical ecology with bacterial genome mining for secondary metabolite discovery
    J. Ind. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 2014; 41:285-299
    Crossref
    Scopus (52)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The metabolomics analysis revealed pathway-dependent molecular features, and a large-scale cultivation was implemented to garner a feasible amount of those metabolites by high-resolution mass-directed isolation for further studies (i.e., NMR-based structural elucidation, absolute configuration analysis, and bioactivity investigation). A starter culture of the full pathway prepared as described above was used to inoculate 1 × 24 L of the supplemented M9 medium, and cultivation was proceeded with identical conditions as used for the metabolomics studies. The culture was centrifuged at 14,000 × g (r.t.) for 30 min, and the clarified supernatants were incubated with XAD-7 HP resins for 2 h (37°C and 180 rpm). The pooled filtered resins were extracted with MeOH (24 L in total), and the methanolic extract was filtered and evaporated under reduced pressure with a stream of nitrogen gas to produce the crude material. The crude extract (∼200 g) was subjected to a gravity column packed with LiChroprep RP18 (500 g; 5 × 20 cm) with a step-gradient elution (0→100% MeOH in water, 10% MeOH increment, 500 mL each) to generate 11 fractions (Fr.1–Fr.11). Among these fractions, Frs.6 and 7 were found to contain target entities based upon single quadrupole LC-MS analysis. These two fractions were combined (Fr.6-7) and further purified employing prep RP HPLC equipped with an Agilent Polaris C18-A column (5→50% MeCN in water with 0.01% TFA for 60 min, 8 mL/min, 1 min collection interval). The LC-MS traces of these HPLC fractions showed that Fr. 6-7→15–25 possessed the targeted metabolites based on their masses and retention times. Repetitive semi-prep HPLC experiments (Phenomenex Luna C18(2); 5→10% MeCN in water with 0.01% TFA) led to the individual purification of the targeted entities. Feeding studies to corroborate the biosynthetic pathway from 2 to 4 were performed with the addition of 1 mM of 2 to the pathway with tybC knocked out. 100 mM IPTG was used for induction. A similar protocol was employed to identify a fatty acid to comprise m/z 753; 1 mM of octanoate was added to the full pathway cultivation together with IPTG induction (Data S3).

    Stereochemical assignment

    The configuration of the tyrosine motif was established as S via Marfey’s analysis (Bhushan and Brückner, 2004
    10.
    Bhushan, R. ∙ Brückner, H.
    Marfey’s reagent for chiral amino acid analysis: a review
    Amino Acids. 2004; 27:231-247
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The stereochemical assignment of the carbohydrate moiety was accomplished utilizing rotating frame Overhauser effect spectroscopy (ROESY) NMR analysis, and the absolute structures of both 2 and phospho-tyrolose (1) were confirmed using synthetic standards (via a Zn2+-catalyzed reaction; Chanda and Harohally, 2018
    22.
    Chanda, D. ∙ Harohally, N.V.
    Revisiting Amadori and Heyns synthesis: critical percentage of acyclic form play the trick in addition to catalyst
    Tetrahedron Lett. 2018; 59:2983-2988
    Crossref
    Scopus (9)
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Relative quantification of tyrocitabine production across strains

    E. coli, K. aerogenes, P. putida, and S. enterica were domesticated with integrated landing pads for T7RNAP production, which was modulated with an induction gradient of theophylline. In B. subtilis, this landing pad was present on the pBroad vector. Pathways were cloned on the conjugative pPath vector, which site-specifically integrates into the landing pad in bacteria, and can be dually maintained centromerically in S. cerevisiae. For Gram-negative bacteria, pathway expressing strains were cultured in 5 mL M9 minimal medium supplemented with 0.4% glucose + 0.2% casamino acids at 30 °C. Upon reaching OD600 0.6, inducers were added, and cultures grown further for 48 hours at 20 °C. For Gram-positive bacteria, pathway expressing strains were cultured in 5 mL LB at 30 °C. Upon reaching OD600 0.6, inducers were added, and cultures grown further for 48 hours at 30 °C. For yeast, cultures were grown in 5 mL complete synthetic medium (CSM) with 2% glucose for 48 hours at 30 °C. Complete cultures were then dried via vacuum using a GeneVac system at full vacuum and no added heat. Once dried, metabolites were extracted with 500 uL methanol. Brief heating at 60 °C and sonication were applied until the extraction produced a homogenous slurry. The slurry was centrifuged at 15000 × g for 10 mins to pellet debris and clarified supernatant was loaded for LC/MS (Agilent QTOF 6550) analysis (1 uL injection volume). Resulting data was analyzed with Agilent Quantitative Analysis software – EIC integrations were performed with 20 ppm error, using exact m/z masses calculated by ChemDraw Pro.

    Detection of metabolites in Lactobacillus iners LEAF 2052A_d

    L. iners was cultivated on Chocolate Agar at 37 °C in anaerobic conditions for 48 hours until visible colonies appeared. Colonies were inoculated into liquid NYCIII medium and further cultivated for 48 hours in anaerobic conditions. Cultures were diluted 1:100 into 5mL fresh NYCIII medium. After overnight incubation, inducers (aTc, tetracycline, and mucin) were added and cultures continued to grow for 24 hours. Cultures were dried under vacuum at RT, and extracted with 500μL methanol. The slurry was centrifuged at 15000 × g for 10 mins to pellet debris and clarified supernatant was loaded for LC/MS (Agilent QTOF 6550) analysis (1 uL injection volume). Resulting data was analyzed with Agilent Quantitative Analysis software.

    In vitro transcription/translation reaction

    The PURExpress kit (NEB) was used in accordance with manufacture’s protocol to assay for the in vitro production of GFP. For each sample a 25 uL reaction was performed containing 100 ng DNA or 500 ng RNA template encoding GFP (transcription in this kit is via T7RNAP), plus indicated amounts of purified compound dissolved in H2O. Reactions were loaded into a white 384 well plate and production of fluorescent GFP protein was monitored with a Synergy Ht Plate Reader (Bio-tek). Fluorescence reached an endpoint at 4 hours. To produce DNA template, a PCR product of the pT7-GFP gene was amplified (Kapa HiFi Polymerase) and purified by gel electrophoresis followed by gel purification (Qiagen). To produce RNA template, the DNA PCR product was transcribed with the HiScribe T7 High Yield RNA Synthesis kit (NEB), treated with DNase1, and purified by the Monarch RNA Purification Kit (NEB). RNA was quantified by Qubit.

    Purification of proteins for in vitro biochemistry reactions

    To purify His-tagged proteins for in vitro biochemistry, individual genes were cloned into a pET28a vector backbone, preserving the N-terminal His tag of the vector, and transformed into E. coli BL21(DE3). Cells were inoculated into 1L terrific broth with kanamycin selection, and cultured at 37 °C shaking at 250RPM. At OD600 0.6, 200μM IPTG was added and cultures incubated for an additional 12 hours at 20 °C. Cultures were centrifuged at 4000rpm for 20 minutes to pellet cells. The pellet was resuspended in 8mL His lysis buffer (50mM NaH2PO4, 300mM NaCl, 10mM Imidazole, adjusted to pH 7.4) + 10mg Lysozyme + 1 cOmplete EDTA-free protease inhibitor tablet (Roache). The suspension was incubated at RT for 30 minutes, then sonicated (10 seconds on, 10 seconds off at 60% amplitude for 3 mins). Cellular debris was pelleted by centrifugation at 14000g for 30 minutes. The debris was re-extracted with 1.5mL Solulyse reagent (AmsBio) for 10 minutes at RT. Debris was pelleted by centrifugation at 14000g for 10 minutes and lysate collected. 1mL Nickel NTA resin was equilibrated in a chromatography column with 2mL His wash buffer (100mM Tris-HCl, 300mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, 20mM Imidazole, adjusted to pH 7.4). Lysate was added and incubated with resin for 60 minutes with gentle agitation. Column was washed twice with 3mL His wash buffer and once again with 3mL His wash buffer containing 50mL Imidazole. 1mL His elution buffer (100mM Tris-HCl, 300mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, 250mM Imidazole, adjusted to pH 7.4) was added and incubated with resin for 60 minutes with gentle agitation. After eluting, 2 subsequent 1mL elutions were performed. Elutions were concentrated in 10kD centrifugation filters (Amicon) and buffer exchanged into PBS. Protein concentration was measured by BCA assay (Pierce). SDS-PAGE gels were used to assess purity of individual elution fractions.

    In vitro biochemistry reactions

    TybC reactions were performed in a buffer of 100mM Tris and 10mM MgCl2, adjusted to pH 7.4. Substrates (L-Tyr and ribose donors) were used at 1mM, and enzyme was used at 10μM. TybE reactions were performed in a buffer of 100mM Tris and 10μM ZnCl2, adjusted to pH 7.4. Substrates (tyrolose and phosphor-tyrolose) and co-factors (NADH and NADPH) were used at 1mM, and enzyme was used at 10μM. TybB reactions were performed in a buffer of 100mM Tris, 10mM MgCl2, 10mM KCl, 10mM DTT, adjusted to pH 7.4. Tyrolose and tyrolitol were used at 1mM, ATP was used at 6mM, and enzyme was used at 10μM. For each, 20uL reactions were incubated for 1 hour at 37 °C, quenched with equal parts acetonitrile, and were loaded for LC/MS (Agilent QTOF 6550) analysis. Resulting data was analyzed with Agilent Quantitative Analysis software – EIC integrations were performed with 20 ppm error, using exact m/z masses calculated by ChemDraw Pro.

    Isolation of total RNA for RT-qPCR experiments

    To collect RNA from S. cerevisiae, 3 mL cultures were grown overnight at 30 °C in YPD media + hygromycin for selection. Cultures were back-diluted 1:50 into fresh medium and grown until OD600 1.0. 1 mL of this culture was processed using the RNeasy Plus Kit (Qiagen), using the manufacturer’s zymolase protocol for lysis. To collect RNA from E. coli, 3 mL cultures were grown overnight at 37 °C in LB + 50 ug/mL carbenicillin for selection. Cultures were back-diluted into fresh medium and grown until OD600 0.6. 0.5 mL of this culture was processed using the RNeasy Plus Kit (Qiagen) using the manufacturer’s lysozyme protocol for lysis. In all cases, in-column DNase treatment and the gDNA removal column were used to eliminate gDNA. Total RNA was quantified by nanodrop. Approximately 100 ng RNA was used in each 20 uL qPCR reaction using the Luna one-step universal RT-qPCR kit (NEB) run on a CFX Connect RT system (Bio-Rad). The cycling conditions were: (1) 55 °C for 10 min (2) 95 °C for 1 min (3) 95 °C for 10 sec (4) 60 °C for 30 sec (5) Measure SYBR (6) Goto step 3, 40x (7) melt curve analysis 60 °C to 95 °C.

    Prediction of Tyb pathway homologs

    The amino acid sequence for the TybB tRNA synthetase protein was used to Blast “All genomes” on the DOE Integrated Microbial Genomes & Microbes (IMG) database with an E-value cutoff of 1e-5. Of the resulting 113 homologs found, each was manually curated to verify that the synthetase lacked an RNA binding domain, as predicted by the InterPro server, and that it was co-localized in an operon containing at least one additional biosynthetic enzyme, resulting in 92 hits. We observed 24 general operon architectures, which are shown in Figure 7B. A species-level phylogenetic tree was constructed with phyloT, populated with NCBI taxonomy data, and visualized with iTOL. Operon schematics were constructed with the Python package DNAplotlib. Additionally, an alternate phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the relatedness of the tRNA synthetases in the pathways, shown in Data S3. For this organizational scheme, all tRNA synthetases were pairwise aligned using the MUSCLE aligner. Finally, to perform a gene cluster-level BLAST search, cBlaster was used with the parameters - E value max: 0.01; Min sequence identity: 20%; Minimum hits: 2; and Require: TybB. To cleanly visualize the results in Figure S8, strains from the same species were condensed into single entries. The raw, uncondensed data can be found in Data S5.

    Chemical synthesis of tyrolose and tyrolitol standards

    The synthesis of tyrolose (2) was achieved with reference to a previous study deliberating Amadori and Heyns synthesis (Chanda and Harohally, 2018
    22.
    Chanda, D. ∙ Harohally, N.V.
    Revisiting Amadori and Heyns synthesis: critical percentage of acyclic form play the trick in addition to catalyst
    Tetrahedron Lett. 2018; 59:2983-2988
    Crossref
    Scopus (9)
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, L-Tyr (1 g) was added into an Erlenmeyer flask with 70 mL MeOH and 5 mL of acetic acid. Subsequently, D-ribose (1 g) was loaded into the reaction flask followed by Zn(OAc)2 (10 mg) and the reaction mixture was refluxed. The reaction progress was monitored every 2 h with single-quadrupole LC-MS analysis, and upon ∼6 h the reaction was completed. The resultant solution was passed through Celite 545 and the infiltrate was dried under vacuum and subjected to prep RP HPLC equipped with an Agilent Polaris C18-A column (5→50% MeCN in water with 0.01% TFA for 60 min, 8 mL/min, 1 min collection interval). The generated HPLC fractions were analyzed with single-quad LC-MS and tyrolose was detected in Frs. 16-24. Synthetic tyrolose was analyzed with the natural one utilizing QTOF-MS to verify the structural assignment of natural tyrolose. Tyrolitol and other tetrahydroxypentyl tyrosines were synthetically prepared with appropriate pentoses using a reported reductive amination synthetic strategy (Wang et al., 2007
    131.
    Wang, Y. ∙ Bi, L. ∙ Hou, B. ...
    Design and synthesis of pentahydroxylhexylamino acids and their effect on lead decorporation
    Chem. Res. Toxicol. 2007; 20:609-615
    Crossref
    Scopus (8)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ): to a mixture of 0.40 g of NaOH in 3 mL of MeOH/H2O (1.5 mL each), 10 mmol of L-tyrosine was charged and stirred at room temperature until the amino acid was dissolved fully. D-ribose, arabinose, lyxose, or xylose (1.5 g) was added and the reactions were kept at room temperature to dissolve each pentose. Under nitrogen protection, the mixtures were subjected to 50-60 °C for 5 h. An ice bath was used to cool the reactions before addition of sodium borohydride (1 g), otherwise a significant amount of hydrogen gas was generated abruptly. The sodium borohydride-mediated reduction was performed at room temperature and the production of tyrolitol and tetrahydroxypentyl tyrosines were examined with single quadrupole LC-MS analysis. Upon completion of the reductions, the reaction mixtures were again cooled to 0 °C and the pH was adjusted to 2.5. The crudes were then concentrated and subjected to RP-HPLC purification (Agilent Polaris C18-A column, 5→20% MeCN in water with 0.01% TFA for 60 min, 8 mL/min, 1 min collection interval). Synthetic tyrolitol and related products were detected in Frs. 10-15 and chromatographically compared to natural materials using HPLC-QTOF-MS analysis, which confirmed the structure of natural tyrolitol and the degradation product of tyrocitabine-626 (4). To produce degradation products for study, tyrocitabine-626 (4) was placed in acidic H2O (pH 4) for two weeks at r.t., and analyzed utilizing QTOF-HPLC-MS along with other tetrahydroxypentyl tyrosines (Data S3).

    Quantification and statistical analysis

    Statistical notes

    For all statistical analysis and curve fitting, the software GraphPad Prism was used. For determining r2 correlation values (Figures 3G, 3H, and 3I), we performed ordinary least squares (OLS) linear regression. For determining statistical significance, a 2-tailed t-test was performed. For statistical significance, the cutoff is ∗ p < 0.05. For all flow cytometry and plate reader data, individual conditions were collected as biological replicates, and for each replicate at least 50000 cells were quantified. Where error bars are shown, mean and standard deviation are plotted. Similarly, for all LC/MS quantification of metabolite production, and quantification of violacein production, 5mL cultures were grown in biological triplicate and extracted, with significance quantified with a 2 tailed t-test.
    For quantifying significance in the difference between the distributions in Figure 2E, a 2-tailed paired Z-test was performed using mean, variance, and sample size of the frequency distributions calculated by GraphPad Prism. The significance level tested against the null hypothesis was p < 0.001.

    Measurement of relative gene expression with RT-qPCR

    For the calculation of mRNA gene expression of the reporter mUkGFP used to evaluate the yeast promoters (Figure 3G), the ΔΔCq method was used (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001
    73.
    Livak, K.J. ∙ Schmittgen, T.D.
    Analysis of relative gene expression data using real-time quantitative PCR and the 2−ΔΔCT method
    Methods. 2001; 25:402-408
    Crossref
    Scopus (120231)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). For these experiments, an equivalent plasmid backbone which lacked a defined yeast promoter upstream of GFP was as the control. Values are plotted as a fold change over this no-promoter control. As internal reference genes for normalization, for S. cerevisiae UBC6 was used, and for E. coli cysG was used. Samples were collected as biological triplicates.

    Measurement of IC50 values

    To quantify IC50 values for translation inhibition activity (Figure 6E), raw fluorescence values were linearly converted to percent activity. The fluorescence of the no template control was used to background subtract the data set and activity was proportionally scaled relative to the no inhibitor control. GraphPad Prism was used to plot a hyperbolic non-linear regression.

    Cookie Preference Center

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
